replies.bodyText:
There was ONE reason why I didn't name it that way, but it's trivial enough reason that I can just worry about it later.
So there is BoundedKeyValue type that extends ImageFeature (no longer in this PR since it's for Predictions.identify()), and I added getKey() and getValue() methods to it to return its key and value, respectively. Now it will be forced to return the whole key-value pair upon calling BoundedKeyValue#getValue().
replies.author: raphkim

replies.bodyText:
Ahhh, yea. Like boundedKeyValue.getValue().getValue() // OMG, Value three times in a row?
Hmmm.

replies.bodyText: Hmm I wasn't too keen on maintaining a list of features we support detecting, but I guess it wouldn't matter too much. I guess it would be good for the future code change I had in mind when I implemented abstract Feature class.
replies.author: raphkim

timeline.bodyText:
Just me ranting here, please disregard -- I'm slightly torn over this:
In a few places, you include links to AWS services that would implement this category in a plugin.
The thing is, these documents are useful!
But, they're about the plugin implementation, not the core category.
Overall, I think they're helping more than they're hurting though. If we removed them, it would be for ideological purity, not for our customer's benefit.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: Yea I felt the same conflict in my head as I wrote these. But in the end, AWS Amplify IS still an AWS product. While I am always striving to make our use-cases as generic as possible, I don't think we should actively fight ideas just because they originated from us.
replies.author: raphkim

timeline.bodyText:
Okay, but where are you getting this list, anyway? It looks like it has become smaller and more manageable?
Is this a list of languages that are supported in an AWS service? If so, we should figure out a way to specify this in the plugin, not in the category.

replies.bodyText: I did fetch it from the list of languages supported by AWS Comprehend and AWS Translate. I think language types is a generic enough concept to be something core to predictions category, so it should be fine. If your concern is regarding whether this list is sufficient, we can always take in github issues to expand upon this list by fellow plugin developers.

timeline.bodyText:
Thanks for adding all this documentation.
These values, "ADJ", "ADP", etc. -- are these specific to a/some AWS services?
If they are, we should use generic values, e.g. "adjective", etc., and then perform a mapping in the plugin. The AWS-specific names for these things would be mapped into the generic category language, thus fully encapsulating the AWS service implementation details.
